awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Energy Efficient Voltage Controlled Non-volatile Domain Wall Devices for Neural Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
As Deep Neural Networks (DNNs) are increasingly deployed in low power embedded device and Internet of Things (IoT) applications. They need to be able to learn in real time while also being energy efficient. This necessitates the use of multi-state memory which is more than the conventional binary “0” and “1” states, is non-volatile such that information is retained when power is turned off, and can be programmed with very little energy. The goal of this project is to study and demonstrate synaptic elements of a neural network, which can store the weights updated during learning using voltage-controlled magnetic domain wall (DW) devices.  Information is encoded as the position of a DW in a narrow magnetic wire. Specifically, the research will focus on using the strain generated by application of a small voltage to a thin piezoelectric layer and transferred to a magnetic wire deposited on it to control DW position in an extremely energy efficient manner. This research could lead to a dense, energy efficient and robust hardware paradigm for implementing DNNs. Two graduate students, one at Virginia Commonwealth University (VCU) and one at Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), will gain multidisciplinary skills in advanced nanofabrication, nano-characterization and modeling. The VCU-PI and MIT- Co-PI will incorporate domain wall technology for memory and computing in the courses they teach. The PI and Co-PI plan to host research interns in their labs recruited from outreach programs for underrepresented groups in their respective universities. The students will be trained on nanofabrication of nanomagnets and other aspects of magnetic technology. The PI and Co-PI also plans to hold nanomagnetism workshops for high school students and teachers in their Universities collaboratively. 

This collaborative effort between VCU and MIT work will study and demonstrate the use of racetracks comprised of magnetostrictive metals such as CoFe, where DWs are moved using Spin Orbit Torque (SOT) from an adjoining Pt layer and arrested deterministically using voltage generated strain from a piezoelectric layer underneath that modulate perpendicular magnetic anisotropy (PMA) in different regions of a racetrack. The research team further plan to explore the use of magnetostrictive Rare Earth Iron Garnets (REIG) that have lower saturation magnetization and low damping, allowing for lower SOT applied for lesser time due to large DW velocities in order to improve the energy efficiency of DW devices. The proposed work will consist of complementary materials growth, characterization, nanofabrication, advanced magnetic visualization, modeling and simulation that includes: (i) Growth of metallic ferromagnetic and insulating ferrimagnets (ii) Study of SOT-driven DW velocity in magnetostrictive racetracks and proof-of-concept demonstration of arresting SOT-driven DW motion with a voltage induced strain (iii) Performing micromagnetic modeling of domain wall motion with SOT and its control with voltage-induced strain in the presence of notches, edge effects and room temperature thermal noise and evaluating the overall performance benefit of the proposed device in implementing DNNs.  The research in this project will advance the knowledge of DW dynamics under local voltage- induced variations in anisotropy, in heterostructures that exhibit rich physics of SOT and the presence of chiral DWs. It will also provide a proof-of-concept demonstration of synaptic and neuron devices that could pave the way for energy-efficient hardware implementation of DNNs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Artificial Intelligence (AI) is creating a need for an enormous amount of data to be processed each year, which is growing exponentially. For this to be sustainable, AI processors need to be energy efficient. This can be achieved by incorporating processing in-memory (PIM), which would benefit from the development of multi-state non-volatile memory (has multiple resistance states that are retained when power is turned off). One such non-volatile memory is based on nanoscale magnets and is called magnetic tunnel junction (MTJ) in which switching the magnetization of the free layer from pointing "up" to "down" encodes a "0" or "1" state. Interestingly, multi-state non-volatile memory can be achieved using nanoscale magnetic racetracks hosting a magnetic domain wall (DW). The DWs can be translated by different distances from one end of the racetrack to achieve multi-state memory. Spin orbit torque (SOT) current and voltage control can reduce the energy consumption for moving and controlling such DWs in nanoscale racetracks compared to the use of spin transfer torque (STT).

Towards this end, we proposed the use of the DW based racetrack MTJ devices to implement synaptic weights in deep neural networks (DNNs). Considering the small footprint of the nanoscale racetrack devices and practical inhomogeneity of the devices, the number of states that can be generated using such DW-MTJs can be small (such as 5-states) and have a stochastic distribution. By employing algorithms that can accommodate the limited resolution of the synaptic weights and stochasticity, we have shown that we can achieve competitive classification accuracies of DNNs and convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and anomaly detection accuracies with autoencoder networks that are almost as accurate as using 32-bit precision weights. Additionally, we have shown that the energy consumption for inference can be at least one order of magnitude smaller using DW based racetrack MTJ compared to Complementary Metal-Oxide-Semiconductor (CMOS) based synaptic memory implementation in neural networks. This approach can lead to sustainable computing due to low power and is also attractive for edge computing and IoTs where both power and hardware resources are limited.

Furthermore, we explored the static and dynamic coupling of a metallic ferromagnet with insulating rare earth ferrimagnet garnets. This creates a pathway for fast ferrimagnet devices, while exploiting the coupling with the ferromagnet that can be incorporated into the soft layer of a MTJ for electrical read-out with high tunnel magnetoresistance. Additionally, we experimentally demonstrated voltage induced strain mediated modulation of perpendicular magnetic anisotropy (PMA) of rare earth garnets such as Bismuth substituted Dysprosium Iron Garnet on PMN-PT.

The results of this project have enabled raising funds towards market discovery and potential proof-of-concept demonstration to commercialize the basic research. Two PhD students have been supported at Virginia Commonwealth University (VCU) and gained nanofabrication, characterization, and computational modeling skills and one of them has also undergone training in commercialization. Six journal papers have been published and a couple more are under preparation, while several invited and contributed conference presentations have been made on this work. A graduate course on nanomagnetism with a module/section of domain walls was taught. One undergraduate student spent 1-2 years as a research intern and worked on machine learning for this project and co-authored a journal paper. A K-12 student spent about two semesters on experimental study of nanomagnets, while STEM outreach from this project involved several K-12 students including from underrepresented groups through workshops and events organized by Richmond Joint Engineering Council in 2022 and 2023.
